g.text: cacy of combined adductor canal block
Yanan Li, MD, Aixiang Li, MD, Yixuan Zhang, MD
This meta-analysis aimed to evaluate the ef
ciency and safety of the combined adductor canal block (ACB) with local
ltration anesthesia (LIA) versus LIA alone for pain control after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
We searched PubMed, Medline, Embase, Web of Science, the Cochrane Library and Google databases from inception
to August 2017 to selected studies that comparing the combined ACB with LIA and LIA alone for pain control after TKA. Only
randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were included. Outcomes included visual analogue scale (VAS) with rest or mobilization at 8 h, 24
h and 48 h, total morphine consumption at 6 h, 24 h and 48 h, distance walked at 24 h and 48 h and the length of hospital stay.
nally included in this meta-analysis. The present meta-analysis indicated
that, compared with LIA alone, combined ACB with LIA was associated with a reduction of VAS with rest at 24 h and 48 h and VAS
with mobilization at 24 h. Additionally, combined ACB with LIA was associated with an increase of the distance walked at 24 h and a
reduction of the length of hospital stay.
Combined ACB with LIA could signi
cantly reduce pain scores and morphine consumption compared LIA alone after
TKA. Further multimodal large sample RCTs are needed to identify the optimal drug of ACB and LIA.
reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses, RCTs
ltration anesthesia, meta-analysis, total knee arthroplasty
Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) has been shown as an ef
operation in improving functional outcome and reliving pain for
patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis
It has been estimated that TKA patients will reach 3.5
patients experience severe pain and moderate pain respectively after
Various analgesia strategies have been implemented
anesthesia (LIA), peripheral nerve block and epidural analgesia.
Adductor canal block (ACB) is a new technique resulting in
sensory blockade that can be easily visualized at the middle third
of the thigh with use of ultrasonography.
analgesic and gained popularity because of the small impact on
the quadriceps muscle weakness. Thus, there was a low risk of
postoperative falls. In addition, it could be implemented with a
high success rate. LIA is considered an alternative choice for
The procedure can be performed without
anaesthetists. Its simplicity and apparent safety gained popularity
for pain control in orthopedic surgery. However, a short duration
of action limits the clinical application. Therefore, combined
analgesia. Whether the combined ACB and peri-articular
ltration provide superior analgesia compared peri-articular
ltration alone after TKA remains controversial.
Thus, we performed a meta-analysis from randomized controlled
ciency and safety of the combined
ACB with LIA versus LIA alone for pain control after TKA.
This systematic review was reported according to the preferred
reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses
We manually searched PubMed, Medline, Embase, Web of
Science, the Cochrane Library and Google databases from
inception to August 2017. The search strategies in Pubmed
